### 🏆 Challenge #6 - DIVISION II

In this challenge we are going to create an application that will take in data from a CSV file containing information about movies and then use that data to build a recommender model using scikit-learn's PCA algorithm. After building your model, we want you to make predictions by taking user inputs as well as historical preference lists of other people who have used our service before! This way everyone gets personalized suggestions tailored specifically towards what they like instead just getting generic ones off some website where no one knows anything about them at all...

Split the train set into training & testing sets while keeping the ratio same as the original data.
```python
X_train, X_test, y_train, y_test = train_test_split(df[["title", "genre"]], df["rating"], test_size=0.33, random_state=42)

print("Test Set Size   : {}".format(len(X_test)))
```

'''

### Part II - Solution #1
from datetime import date
import pymysql
conn = pymysql.connect(host="localhost", user= "root", passwd='', db="movies")
cur = conn.cursor()
sql="""SELECT tb.* FROM title_basics AS tb JOIN name_basics as na ON tb.`primaryTitle`=na.`primaryName`,
tb.titleType=na.category WHERE tb.isAdult='false' AND na.job LIKE 'Actor%' OR na.job LIKE 'Director%' ORDER BY tb.startYear DESC"""
cur.execute(sql)
data=cur.fetchall()
for i in data[::-1]:
    print("Title : "+str(i[6])+"\nYears : "+ str(date.today().year)-int((i[7].split('-')[0]))+1," - "+str(date.today().year)+"\nGenre :"+i[8]+"\nSummary : "+i[9]+"\nIMDB Ratio : "+i[10]+" / 10 \nCast Members : "+i[11][:-1]+" ")

### 76. Create an index in MySQL
In order to improve performance when retrieving data from your databases you may want to create indexes. Indexes are used by the Database Management System (DBMS) to speed up certain types of queries against the underlying table structure. For example if we wanted to retrieve all rows containing the word "Science" then using an index allows us to quickly find those rows instead of having to scan every row in our table one-by-one which could take time depending upon how many records there are within each column being searched through. In addition indexing also helps reduce disk IO operations since most searches will return fewer than ten items per page so less pages means less reads/writes onto disks thus reducing wear & tear over long periods due increased usage patterns such as reading large amounts at once multiple times throughout day etc..

# Importing the libraries
import pandas as pd
from sklearn import datasets
from sklearn.model_selection import train_test_split
from matplotlib import pyplot as plt
%matplotlib inline
df = pd.read_csv("C:/Users/Aleksandr/Downloads/IMDb-Dataset/imdb_movies.tsv", sep="\t")

# Data preprocessing - split into training and testing data sets
Xtrain= df[["title_ratings","name_basics", "title_crew" ]].dropna().to_numpy()
ytrain = df[["title_principals"]].dropna().to_numpy()
Xval= Xtrain[:len(Xtrain)/6]+Xtrain[-len(Xtrain):]/6 # splitting the dataset in two halves
Xtest=Xtrain[len(Xtrain)/6:] # splitting the dataset in half again
Ytest= ytrain[len(ytrain)/6:]
Xtrain = np.array([i for i in range(-len(Xtrain), len(Xtrain))]) + 1

# Feature scaling
scaler = StandardScaler()
Xscaled = scaler.fit_transform(Xtrain)
plt.scatter(Xscaled[:,-1], Ytrain)

# Creating the model
clf = LinearRegression()
clf.fit(Xscaled, Ytrain )
prediction = clf.predict(Xtest).astype('int')

# Visualizing accuracy of predictions using ROC curve plotting
roc_curve = roc_auc_score(Ytest, prediction)
print ('ROC Curve Score : {0}'.format(roc_curve*100))

# Making sure we are not overfitting our model by calculating RMSE score
rmse = sqrt((np.mean((Xtest-prediction)**2)))
print ("Mean Squared Error : {}".format(rmse))

```sql
select title_id as TID from titles where
titleType = "movie" and
(startYear <= 2016 AND endYear >= 2017);

SELECT * FROM (
    SELECT DISTINCT t.*, rr.*, rc.*, c.*
        FROM ratings AS r
            JOIN rating_reviews AS rr ON r.ratingId=rr.ratingId
            LEFT OUTER JOIN reviews AS rc ON r.reviewId=rc.reviewId
            LEFT OUTER JOIN titles AS t ON rc.titleId=t.titleId;
     WHERE
         r.user_name='$username' OR $username IS NULL
             AND r.rating > 5
             AND r.timestamp BETWEEN '$dateFrom' AND '$dateTo';
     ORDER BY SUM(rr.vote) DESC LIMIT $limit;
 ) AS t
JOIN categories AS cat ON t.categoryId=cat.categoryId
GROUP BY t.titleId;
```

'''

def getData(title):
    """Returns all data from IMDb for a given title"""
    
    url = "https://www.imdb.com/find?" + \
          f'q={title}&exact=true&sort=popularity,desc&type=movie'"\
         #+ "&genre=" + genre
        #+ "&rating=1+"
        #+ "&year=&releaseGroup=&language=&pageNum=0&includeAdult=false"

    response = requests.get(url).text
    soup = BeautifulSoup(response,'html.parser')
    return soup.select(".item-list")[0].div["data"].split("\n")

### Task #2 - Recommendation System for Movie Reviews

#### Description

You will use the same data set as described above but now you have additional information about ratings given by viewers of each film. For example, if we take Rear Window again, then its overall score would be 7 out of 10 while individual scores could range between 6/10 and 9/10. Your task is to create an SQL query to show top ten rated movies according to reviews posted online. This means your query must return at least 10 records when run against our dataset. You do not need to rank these movies since there may exist multiple equally-rated movies. In addition, please note that the total number of items returned may exceed 10 because some movies might receive fewer than 10 votes so those ones won’t appear in your final list. Also remember that you don’t necessarily want every possible combination being generated! Instead focus on finding good matches between different types of criteria such as genre vs director etc., which makes sense considering how many different ways people rate things today thanks largely due technology advancements over recent years allowing us access more content faster than ever before…

In this assignment, I am going to implement GAN using Python programming language. ### Part II - Implementing a Recommender System using Machine Learning Techniques ###
Now we want you to implement your SQL queries in code! This means implementing the query generation part of the algorithm as well as training the model so that when new movies are added to the database they will automatically get recommended to people who have watched them before.
The first thing to do is write an implementation of your SQL query from Part I which returns all matching films given some user preference inputs. For example if someone searches for "thrillers" then this query would return a list of matching titles along with each film's rating score out of five stars. If there aren't any matches found then just return null instead since no one wants empty lists returned back anyway right? Next step involves training up our machine learning models by feeding data into these algorithms until they learn how best match similar items together based off past interactions between different individuals within our dataset itself though typically speaking those numbers tend towards being fairly low overall unless perhaps during peak holiday periods where everyone seems interested at once somehow...

In order to train your model, you must gather enough data points about both positive and negative feedback received from viewers regarding certain movies. This information could include ratings given on sites like IMDB or Rotten Tomatoes; comments made online after watching said flick(s); etc.. Once collected, use logistic regression techniques such as SVM classifiers (Support Vector Machines), KNN methods & Neural Network architectures among others depending upon what type/classification problem needs solving here. Then apply whatever appropriate technique suits yer fancy most effectively while keeping things simple yet effective simultaneously. Finally pass these predictions through another layer called “post-processing” wherein additional filters remove irrelevant noise thereby reducing computational costs significantly thus improving performance metrics greatly over time!

To build a recommender system, you’ll need to create a training set consisting of examples of previous customer behavior. This might look something like this:

| Movie Title | User ID | Rating Score | Customer Feedback Comments |
|--------------|-----------|--------------------|-----------------------|
| A Quiet Place  | UID007   | 4                    | It was great!         |
| The Dark Knight | UID006   | 3                     | Not my cup o tea      |
| Black Panther  | UID005  |

In part A you generated a SQL query which will allow you to retrieve data from multiple tables within the IMDb database. Now implement the above query using python and execute it against the IMDb API endpoint /search/advanced.

- `totalResults`: Number of items matched. Must be an integer greater than zero.

		- shortfilm  
		- feature     
		- miniseries  
		- documentary 
		- animated    
		- musicvideo  
		- videoGame  
	- title: Full title of the work including any alternate titles if applicable. For example: "Terminator Genisys", "Pulp Fiction", etc.   
	- plotOutline: Short synopsis of what happens in the story.   
	- language: Primary spoken language(s). Can have more than one value such as English and Japanese.   
	- genreIds: Array of integers representing genres.   
	- releaseDate: Year and month when the item was first released into cinemas or broadcasted. If unavailable then the date range between the earliest possible premiere until now will be displayed instead.

	- voteCount: Total votes cast towards whether they think its good or bad.

### Part Two - Optimization
In part one we have generated an initial set of recommendations using basic filtering techniques such as averaging ratings across movies and selecting top rated titles. In this second part, we want to optimize our query further so that we can produce more accurate recommendations while still keeping things simple enough to maintain performance at scale. For example, imagine there were thousands of movies being queried each day instead just three! To accomplish these goals let's consider two additional optimization strategies:
* Use JOIN operations between multiple table joins rather than nested WHERE clauses within those join statements themselves
* Create indexes over important fields like `genre` or even better combine them into compound indices containing both the genre column plus any other relevant information about specific movies e.g., year released etc...

### Bonus Task #1 - Improved Performance
Now that we know how to improve accuracy through JOINing tables together along with creating index-based optimizations around key data points lets put everything together into one big fat query statement! Let’s try out some different ways of writing this kinda complex query until finally coming up with something super efficient yet readable too :-)

You are required to create an algorithm in Python which will take as inputs two strings representing user preference and the list of available titles in the IMDB database respectively and return a string containing all possible genre matches from the DB. For example if we have the following data set:

**Movie Title** | **Genre(s)**  
---|---
[Gone Girl](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0727576/) | Thriller / Drama / Mystery

[Inception](https://www.imdb.com/title/tt1333611/?ref_=ttpl_pl_tt)? | Sci-Fi / Crime / Mystery

> Thriller + Drama + Mystery
> War + Action & Adventure
> Sci-Fi + Crime + Mystery
> Fantasy + Family + Science Fiction

    print('---------------------- Movie Recommendation System ---\n\n')

    # Randomly select top N number of recommended items
    nRecommendedItems = int(input('\nEnter Top Number Of Items To Be Recommended : '))
    random.shuffle(userPrefHistory)
    recommendedList = []
    for itemIdx in range(nRecommendedItems):
        recommendedItem = random.choice([item for item in userPrefHistory])
        recommendedList.append((recommendedItem, moviesDetails[int(random.randrange(0, len(moviesDetails)-1))]))
                               
    return recommendedList

def getAllMovieIds():
    """Get All ImdB IDs For All Movies In Database."""
    
    movieData = {}

    return sorted(set(movieData.

\begin{blockquote}

\strong{\em{Get user preference history}} - Get all movies watched by the current logged in user from his/her profile page.

\strong{\em{Create list of recommended movies}} - Create a list containing titles of all the movies which have been rated higher than 7 out of 10. For each movie create another list called "related" which contains all other movies related to the main movie. These lists will be used later when generating our final recommendation list.

\strong{\em{Find commonalities between the two lists}} - Find overlapping items between the above created lists. We do this because we want to avoid recommending similar movies to our customer.

\strong{\em{Remove duplicate entries}} - Remove duplicates from both these lists as they may occur due to overlapping elements. Also remove those elements whose rating is lesser than 8 since customers would usually like to watch better quality content rather than mediocre ones.

\strong{\em{Combine the remaining lists into one}} - Combines the remaining elements into a single list ordered according to the average ratings given by the respective users who had watched them.

\strong{\em{Sort the combined list}} - Sort the resulting combined list such that the top few movies appear first followed by the rest.

\strong{\em{Display the finalized list}} - Display the top 10 most popularly rated movies alongwith the number of votes received by each of them.
\end{blockquote}

---|--------------|-----------------

output:
"""

# User Inputs
userInput = ["Can you help me choose a super hero movie?"].split(" ")
movieRecommendationSystem(userInput[0]) # Main Function
print("\n")

# Movie Recommenedation System
def movieRecommendationSystem(input):
    # Variables
    userPrefHistory = []
    
    while True:
        # Get user preference history
        userChoice = str(input()).strip().lower()
        
        if len(userChoice) == 0 : break
            
        elif not any([c in ['click','the avengers','two weeks notice'] for c in userChoice]):
            print('Invalid Input!')
            
        else:
            userPrefHistory += list(userChoice).copy()
                  
                # Check if no more inputs are made
                if len(userChoice)==0: break;
        
    # Generate random number of movie suggestions from user preference history
    randNumOfSuggestions = int((len(userPrefHistory)/2)) + 1
              
    # If there's no user preference history yet, then return empty array
    if len(userPrefHistory) < 1:
      
      print('\n\nNo previous movies selected by your friend so far...')
         
    # Else, get top N recommended movies according to user preference history
    else:
          
      print('\nYou have been suggested {} out of {}.'.format(*userPrefHistory[:randNumOfSuggestions]))

    return userPrefHistory[:randNumOfSuggestions], userPrefHistory[-randNumOfSuggestions:]

### Part II - Movie Recommendation System
#### Database Schema
The database schema you are given below has been simplified from the IMDB dataset. It includes the following tables:
- **movies** contains information about all of the movies in the database;
- **actors** contains actors who have appeared in multiple films;
- **director** contains directors of some of these movies;
- **genre** contains genre labels used by many of these movies;
- **reviewers** contains reviewers of different movies.
You will use an example dataset containing 987 unique reviews, 254 unique titles, and 514 unique actors/directors as your test data set.

Database Tables:  
| Table Name | Columns | Description |
| :---      | ---     | ---         |
| Movies    | mID       | Unique identifier        |
| Actors   | actorID   | Unique identifier          |
| Directors | directorID | Unique identifier        |
| Genres   | genreID   | Unique identifier         |
| Reviewers | reviewerID | Unique identifier        |
| Ratings   | ratingID  | Unique identifier        |
| Titles   | tID        | Unique identifier        |

Columns:  
* mID = movies ID (int);
* actorID = actors IDs (string);
* directorID = directors IDs (string);
* genreID = genre IDs (string);
* reviewerID = reviewers IDs (string);
* ratingID = ratings IDs (string);
* tID = titles IDs (string).

Data Types:  
mID, actorID, directorID, genreID, reviewerID – int(11),
ratingID, tID – string(20).

    SELECT tb.*, nc.*, rr.*, ccc.*, prs.*

            + CASE WHEN prs.[category]=0 then ''else prs.[job]+'' ('+CASE WHEN prs.[characters]=''THEN ''ELSE prs.[character]+ '''')END AS Job
FROM title_basics as tb INNER JOIN name_basics as nc ON tb.title_type=nc.primary_name AND nc.death_year IS NULL LEFT OUTER JOIN title_rating as tr ON tr.movie_id=(tb.title_id OR nc.title_id) INNER JOIN title_crew as tcr ON tb.title_id=tcr.movie_id LEFT OUTER JOIN title_principal as tpc ON tb.title_id=tpcs.movie_id LEFT OUTER JOIN title_recommendation as tgr ON tb.title_id=tgr.movie_id WHERE (((((tr.average_rating>=6 AND tr.num_votes>0)) OR (tr.average_rating>=7))) OR ((((tcr.director LIKE '%Jane Campion%' OR tcr.writer LIKE %'Jane Campion%') OR tcr.director LIKE '%Lynne Ramsay%' OR tcr.writer LIKE '%Lynne Ramsay%')) AND ((((tr.average_rating>=6 AND tr.num_votes>0)))))) AND (((((npcs.[birth_year]=1974 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1975 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1976 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1977 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1978 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1979 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1980 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1981 OR npcs.[birth_year]=1982 OR npcs.[birth_year]=198

Answer: This solution was provided by my professor during our online class session; however, I would like to share here as well in case someone else needs help understanding the concept of "JOIN"s.

\begin{code}
SELECT DISTINCT
    tc.*, rr.averageRating AS rating, rr.numVotes AS votesCount
FROM titles_ratings rr
LEFT JOIN title_crew c ON c.directorID = rr.directorID AND c.writerID = rr.writerID
INNER JOIN name_basics nb ON nb.primaryName = rr.titlePrimaryName
LEFT JOIN title_principals pr ON pr.job = rr.category OR pr.characters LIKE CONCAT('%', rr.characterName,'%)'
WHERE nb.primaryName NOT IN ('Douglas Fairbanks Sr., Douglas Fairbanks Jr.')
AND nb.primaryName <> ''
ORDER BY rating DESC LIMIT 8 OFFSET?
\end{code}

-- Table definitions ------------------------------
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `title_basics` (
    `tconst` int(11) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
    `titleType` varchar(7),
    PRIMARY KEY (`tconst`) USING BTREE,
    UNIQUE INDEX `index_titleBasics_primaryTitle` (`primaryTitle`),
    KEY `index_titleBasics_isAdult` (`isAdult`)
);

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `title_ratings` (
    `tconst` int(11) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
    `averageRating` float(6,2) NOT NULL,
    `numVotes` int(11) NOT NULL AUTO_INCREMENT,
    PRIMARY KEY (`tconst`, `averageRating`) USING BTREE
);

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `name_basics` (
    `nconst` int(11) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
    `primaryName` varchar(100) CHARACTER SET utf8mb4 COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci NOT NULL,
    `birthYear` smallint(6) UNSIGNED DEFAULT NULL,
    `deathYear` smallint(6) UNSIGNED DEFAULT NULL,
    `primaryProfession` varchar(100) CHARACTER SET utf8mb4 COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci DEFAULT NULL,
    PRIMARY KEY (`nconst`) USING BTREE,
    KEY `index_nameBasics_primaryName` (`primaryName`)
);

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `title_crew` (
    `tconst` int(11) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
    `directors` text,
    PRIMARY KEY (`tconst`) USING BTREE
);

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS `title_principals` (
    `tconst` int(11) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
    `ordering` int(11) DEFAULT NULL,
    `nconst` int(11) unsigned DEFAULT NULL,
    `category` tinytext,
    `job` varchar(255) CHARACTER SET utf8mb4 COLLATE utf8mb4_unicode_ci

"""

from sqlalchemy import create_engine, MetaData, Table, Column
from sqlalchemy.sql import func
import sys;
sys.setrecursionlimit(None); # Unlimited recursion depth!
# ----------------------------------------------------------------------------

def main():
    engine = create_engine("sqlite:///:memory:")
    
    # Create an in-memory SQLite DB
    metadata = MetaData()
    metadata.reflector().add_all(Table('title_basic', Column('tconst'), \
                          Column('titleType', String),\
                           Column('primaryTitle','string'),\
                            Column('originalTitle','string'),\
                             Column('isAdult','boolean'),\
                              Column('startYear','integer'),\
                               Column('endYear','integer'),\
                                Column('runtimeMinutes','float')),\
        Table('name_basic',Column('nconst','integer'),\
                   Column('birthYear','integer'),\
                      Column('deathYear','integer'),\
                         Column('primaryProfession','string'),\
                          Column('knownForTitles','string')),\
       Table('title_rating',Column('averageRating','float'),\
                   Column('numVotes','integer')),\
        Table('title_crew',Column('directors','string[]'),\
                    Column('writers','string[]')),\
        Table('title_principal',Column('ordering','integer'),\
                  Column('nconst','integer'),\
                   Column('category','string'),\
                    Column('job','string'),\
                     Column('characters','string[]')))\

    # Create all necessary tables if they don't exist already
    try :
        metadata.create_all(bind=engine)
    except Exception as e :
        print ("An error occurred while creating tables: " + str(e))
        exit(-1)

    userInput = ""
    while True:

        else:

    # Get User Input

    likes = []
    dislikes = []
    while True:

            dislike = str(input("\nEnter any disliked titles you'd want removed from future recommendations:\n"))

            break;

    favlist = list(map(lambda y: "%s" + "," * len("%s" % y), favlist))[::len(favlist)]
    dlst = list(map(lambda z: "%s" + "," * len("%s" % z), dlst)[::len(dlst)])

### 7. Movie Recommendation System - Part II ###

#### Challenge Description ####

Generate an SQL query that will return a list of movies from the IMDb database by using the user's preference history as well as other criteria such as popularity rating. Your solution must include all parts of the challenge description in order to receive full credit. Specifically your code must do ALL of these things below. **Note**: The solution MUST run properly when you submit it so make sure to test before submitting! If any part of the program does not work correctly then you may lose points even if everything else works.

You have been given access to data about different types of movies stored within the IMDB database. For each type of movie there are several attributes including title, year released, genre, cast members etc... Each row represents one specific instance of that particular type of film. In addition we also know how much people liked those films via ratings. We want to find some way to use this information to predict whether someone would like another movie which they haven't seen yet. To accomplish this goal our algorithm needs two pieces of additional information: firstly what kinds of things did they already enjoy watching? Secondly who was involved in making them both? These questions cannot simply be answered directly because there isn't enough time during development phases nor sufficient computing power available at present; however luckily modern machine learning techniques allow us solve these problems fairly easily through simple calculations involving probabilities calculated over large amounts of training examples gathered previously during production runs where similar tasks were performed successfully.

Therefore suppose I ask my friend "What kinda stuff d'you like?" He might respond something along lines :"Well i really dig horror flicks but sometimes action adventures too". So now let me tell him that I've got just perfect suggestion which fits his taste perfectly! That would mean having knowledge about both likes/dislikes & interests (in case he watched some TV series). But wait...there could still exist some unknown factors affecting outcome here..maybe some random events happened somewhere far away causing certain changes leading up towards final conclusion regarding movie selection process itself....so lets try adding more variables into mix until eventually reaching point where probability becomes very close indeed :)

I'm not sure if I have to explain what each column does in my sql statement but here goes...

title_basics - This table contains information about movies such as the year they were released, how long they are etc. Each row has a unique tconst value which acts like an identifier of sorts for a particular movie.
name_basics - This table contains basic info about actors/director/producers etc who worked on certain films. It also includes some general details about them such as age at time of work etc. Again there is a unique nconst field that identifies each person in the database.
title_rating - Here we store ratings given by people using IMDb. These could either be average rating over all votes or total number of voters. In both cases the unique tconst key uniquely identifies individual rows within the table.
title_crew - This table stores links between different roles played by various persons e.g. director = John Doe -> writer = Jane Smith means John directed Jane wrote the script. There is again a unique tconst field used to identify rows in this table.
title_principal - Finally this table holds data about principal cast members in each movie along with other useful fields. Uniqueness is achieved through use of the nconst field.

So essentially from user input you want me to find matching titles from these five tables where the user preference history matches any combination of the above values so that when the user clicks "Get Recommendation" button he gets back a list of possible suggestions.

```sql
SELECT * FROM (SELECT DISTINCT tc.*, nr.*, tcr.*
FROM (title_basic AS tb JOIN name_base as n ON tb.primaryTitle = n.nconst) LEFT OUTER JOIN rating AS r ON tb.tconst=r.tconst AND r.numvotes>=0 RIGHT outer join title_rating tr USING(tconst)
LEFT OUTER JOIN (SELECT DISTINCT tc.tconst, avg(tr.averageRating), count(*) from title_crew TC left outter join title_rating TR using(tc.tconst)) AS tv ON tr.tconst =tv.tconst WHERE (tb.isadult IS NULL OR bb.isadult!= 'true')AND (tb.startyear < 1980 OR bb.startyear > 1979 )and (tb.endyear >= 1960 OR bb.endyear <= 1959) GROUP BY tb.tconst) AS tc LEFT OUTTER JOIN title_crew tcr USING(tconst) group by tc.tconst having COUNT(*)=1 and avgrating>5
```

INNER JOIN (select distinct titleType, castmemberId from movie_ratings where userId=@userId group by castmemberId )as m ON t.titleType=m.titletype AND t.castMemberID=m.castmemberId

```

'''

### Implementation ###

#### User Input ####
userInput = str(input('Enter your search term here'))

#### Historical Preferences #####
movieList = ['Terminator 2: Judgment Day (1991)','Commando  (1985)','Under Siege (1992)'] #list of movies user has watched in past
moviesWatched = len([x for x in movieList if x == userInput])+1 #number of times movie was searched by user before
preferenceHistory = []
for i in range(0,len(movieList)):
    preferenceHistory += [i]*[moviesWatched*i]

#### Generated Recommendation #####
recommendedMovies = sorted(set(movieList), key=lambda k : preferenceHistory.index(k))[:7] + ["None"]
print("The recommended movies are", recommendedMovies)

# Expected Output
# ['The Big Lebowski', 'Mulholland Drive','House Party'].

import requests
from bs4 import BeautifulSoup as BS
class ImdbParser(object):
    def __init__(self):
        self._url = "https://www.imdb.com/search/"
    
    @staticmethod
    def getDataFromUrl():
        r = requests.get('http://www.imdb.com')
        soup = BS(r.text,"html.parser")
        
        imdb_links = []
        movies = soup.findAll("div", {"id": "moviedetail"})
       # print(type(movies))
        if len(movies)>=1 :
            for i in range(len(movies)):
                imdb_link = str(soup.select("#title-main div > h3 > span").first())[6:] + '/'
                  
                #print(i+1,'-',imdb_link[:])
               # print()
                imdb_links += [[i+1, imdb_link]]
            
        return imdb_links

def main():
    parser = ImdbParser().getDataFromUrl()
    print(parser)
if __name__ == '__main__':
    main()

CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS userMovieHistory AS(SELECT * FROM ( SELECT t.title AS titleID, n.name AS actorID, c.category AS genreID, j.job AS jobID, i.characters AS characterID, tc.titleType AS typeID, tb.primaryTitle as titleBasicsID, tr.averageRating as ratingID, nr.numVotes as votesID FROM (title_basics t JOIN cast_members cm ON t.movieID = cm.movieID AND t.movieID IN (cm.movieID)) JOIN crew_member cr ON t.movieID=cr.movieID AND t.movieID in (cr.movieID) WHERE t.movieID <> '' OR t.movieID IS NULL UNION ALL SELECT t.title AS titleID, n.name AS actorID, c.category AS genreID, j.job AS jobID, i.characters AS characterID, tc.titleType AS typeID, tb.primaryTitle as titleBasicsID, tr.averageRating as ratingID, nr.numVotes as votesID from (title_basics t JOIN actors aa ON t.movieID = aa.actorID AND t.movieID IN (aa.actorID) ) JOIN movies m ON t.moviename = m.movieID AND t.movieID IN (m.movieID) WHERE t.movieID <> '' OR t.movieID IS NULL UNION ALL SELECT t.title AS titleID, n.name AS actorID, c.category AS genreID, j.job AS jobID, i.characters AS characterID, tc.titleType AS typeID, tb.primaryTitle as titleBasicsID, tr.averageRating as ratingID, nr.numVotes as votesID from (title_basics t JOIN titles tb ON t.movieID = tb.movieID AND t.movieID IN (tb.movieID) ) JOIN creators cc ON t.movieID = cc.creatorID AND t.movieID IN (cc.creatorID) WHERE t.movieID <> '' OR t.movieID IS NULL UNION ALL SELECT t.title AS titleID, n.name AS actorID, c.category AS genreID, j.job AS jobID, i.characters AS characterID, t

### Part B - Executing the Query

Now that we have generated our SQL query let's execute it using the MySQL command line client. To do so first open up the terminal window by pressing Ctrl+Alt+T. Then run the following commands:
```bash
cd ~/Documents/Database/IMDB-Movie-Recommendation-System
mysql --user=root --password=password <./movieRecom.sql #This will create new database named "imdb"
```
After running these commands you will see something like below:
![](./img/partB-result.png)

Notice how the script created a new empty database called imdb? This was done because there are no existing databases inside the current directory when we ran the above command. Now that we know how to connect to the server successfully let us check what happens if we try to access a non existent database:
```bash
mysql --user=root --password=password
Enter password: ******
ERROR 1045 (28000): Access denied for user 'root'@'localhost' (using password: YES)
```
You may also want to take some time out now and explore other features of MySql CLI such as creating new databases and tables within them. I would encourage you to use the documentation provided here https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/connecting.html to help you get started.

2. title_ratings [tconst, averageRating, numVotes]

User Input: 
I am looking for a fun action movie to watch.
User Preference History: 
['Kingsman: The Secret Service (2014)', 'Skyfall (2012)', 'The Avengers  (2012)', 'The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo  (2009)']
SQL Query:

query: I am wanting to go out and see a movie.  Can you help me find one?
output:
Select * from
(select tb.*, tc.*, tr.*, nr.*, nc.*, tc.*, tw.*, np.*
from imdb.title_basics as tb inner join imdb.name_basics as nc on tb.primaryName=nc.nconst
inner join imdb.title_rating s on tb.title_id =s.tconst
where s.averageRating > 6/10 )
as movies
join imdb.name_basics as nb on movies.primaryName =nb.nconst;
```

	''' Parses user input strings to match against movie data '''

		word = str(re.sub('\W*',' ', word))
		word = re.sub("\d+","", word).strip().lower()
		if len(word)>=2 and word[-1].isupper():
			word += " "
		searchTerm.append((word,""))

	return searchTerm

# Note: We are not providing any sample data as we want you to come up with your own approach to solving the problem. However, if you get stuck at some point please feel free to ask us for help.
'''

def main():
    print("""Welcome to Movie Recommendation System!
        Please enter an integer number of user preference history: """)
    userHistory = int(input()) # userHistory = 3
    
    print("""Enter a string containing the genre of movies you like: """ + "romance" )
    genreOfMovies = input()
        
    #create empty list called favoriteMoviesList which will contain all the favorite movies from user inputs
    favoriteMoviesList=[]
    while len(userHistory)>0 :                     
        print("""Please enter one item per line using format: {title} - {year}""".format({title:"{}"}.format(' '.join([genreOfMovie for genreOfMovie in genreOfMovies]))))
           
        #create another variable called newFavoriteMovies so that every time the loop runs there will be more items added into the favoriteslist  
        newFavoriteMovies = []          
            
        #reads each line until no lines left in the file
        with open ("userInput.txt", "r+") as fh:      
                for i in range(len(userHistory)):              
                        line = fh.next().strip("\n").split(',')
                        newFavoriteMovies += [" ".join([line[i]])]+["-"+str(int(line[(i)+1])])                             
                        favMovies = newFavoriteMovies[-1].replace(" ", "")+" "+newFavoriteMovies[-1][:-1]
                        print("{} has been saved.".format(favMovies),file=sys.stderr)
                        sys.stdout.flush()         
                        break
                        
        #adds elements to the existing list by appending them onto the last element and then returns the updated list
        favoriteMoviesList+=newFavoriteMovies[:]
                
        #removes the first element from the array

Example:

Movie Recommendation System
The system will first retrieve all movies which have a rating greater than two stars from the title ratings table by using the WHERE clause “titleRatings > = ‘2’” followed by an ORDER BY clause to sort them descendingly according to the average of these titles. Then, the system retrieves all actors who are not part of any crew members but whose names appear at least once within the character field in the principal casts table. Finally, the system joins both data sets together and uses the INNER JOIN operation to find those actors who appeared more frequently than other actors in movies rated above two stars.

### Example 6 - E-commerce Website
Implement an e-Commerce website using a relational database management system of your choice where customers can place orders online. Your website must support at least three different types of products which are categorised as follows;
1. Books [ISBN Number, Title, Author Name, Publisher Name, Publication Year].
2. Clothes [Size, Colour, Brand, Price Per Item, Quantity in Stock].
3. Toys [Brand, Type, Price per Unit, Number of Units In Stock].
You will also require a table that contains customer details including email address, phone number and delivery postcode. Whenever a user places an order they have two options, either collect from store location or receive by courier service. If they select courier then you will create another table called `Couriers` containing information about each individual courier company such as their name, cost per item, minimum/maximum weight limit and time taken between collection point and delivery destination.

### Example 7 - Hotel Booking System
Design a hotel booking application that uses MySQL as its backend. This app needs to allow visitors to search hotels within specific locations according to various criteria such as star rating, price range etc., and make reservations accordingly. It would also need some sort of payment gateway integration so that when people check out after their stay there’d be no problem making payments via credit card or other means if required. Finally include features like notifications sent out whenever someone makes changes regarding their existing reservation(s).

### Example 8 - Car Rental Database
This project involves designing a car rental database that includes all necessary fields for storing data related to cars available for rent along with their respective prices and terms & conditions applicable upon usage. Users may view these items through searching or browsing functions provided by our web interface while admin panel provides access control over what kind of privileges each member has across entire site content.

### Example 9 - Library Management System
A library management system allows patrons to borrow books from libraries worldwide. A typical LMS consists of four main components: User Interface (UI), Data Storage Engine (DSE), Network Communication Protocol Stack (NCPS), and Software Development Kit (SDK). These components work together seamlessly providing powerful functionality while ensuring high performance throughout operations.

### Task 7 - 8/16 points
In your solution, you will write an application using JavaFX. This app must have at least two text fields where one field displays the user’s favorite movies and another field displays recommended titles based upon those favorites. The app needs to accept new entries from the user of additional favorite movies as well as add them to the list of previous entries. It also has to allow deletion of any entry previously added by the user. Finally, when the “Recommend” button is clicked, the program should display its findings.

You may use any GUI library such as Swing, SWT or JavaFx but not AWT!

Note that the recommendation process involves matching each entered movie against all other movies already stored in memory. For example, if there are ten movies in total, then the recommendation algorithm would compare every possible pair-wise combination between these movies. As we increase the number of movies in our dataset, this operation becomes more time consuming since the number of comparisons increases exponentially. Therefore, we want to store fewer movies in order to avoid wasting too much CPU resources during computation. However, storing less data than what might actually be useful could lead us into making poor choices about which films deserve inclusion within our collection. Thus, we seek some middle ground here; namely, finding ways to balance between keeping enough information while still being able to perform fast searches later downstream after having collected everything firsthand via manual intervention rather than relying solely upon automated processes alone.

### Task #6 - Relational Database Design
The goal of this challenge is to create an accurate relational schema design using proper ER diagram techniques. Your solution must include at least two entities in your ER Diagram along with one relationship between those entities.

Database Schema: 
An organization has five different departments within its business structure. Each department stores data about employees who work there. There are three types of employees; regular employee, managerial position, director level, and executive positions.
Employees have various information stored such as hire date, last promotion date, current salary, highest paying yearly bonus received, current benefits package, and many more. Managers also track how much time they spend meeting with each team member and what projects they were working on when they met. Directors keep records regarding which companies they represent clients for during meetings with potential partners/clients while executives maintain detailed files containing all kinds of important documents related specifically towards their role within corporation itself including contractual agreements signed off upon by both parties involved etc...

### Part C - Bonus Challenge

Now imagine there is an extra column called genre_counts which contains a count value for each row in the genre table. This means if we had one row like this:

| Title | Genre Count   |
---     | ---           |
| Black Widow        | 1            |
| Guardians Of The Galaxy | 1         |

then the total number of times "action" was mentioned would be two because both those titles were listed as having at least one element of "Action". Similarly, the total number of times "comedy" appeared was also two since they both contained at least one element of comedy. Note that the genre counts do not add up exactly to the total number of unique elements because some titles may contain multiple elements such as "thriller", "drama", etc...

### 176. Recommendation System - Part Two

[LeetCode link](https://leetcode.com/problems/recommender-system/)

Given an array of items and a user's ratings of each item in the form of nonnegative integers. Find all pairs of distinct items whose sum is equal to the given target number T. Note that you may return multiple pairs of items if there exists more than one pair such that both sums of the two corresponding sets of items equals T. If no valid set exists, then return [-1,-1]. Example: Given A=[1,2,3], B=[4,5,6], C=[7,8,9] and the target value is 12, find all possible pairs of values that will give us the total score of 12 when we add up these numbers. So here we have three arrays but we want to compare them against another set which has been defined as a constant variable "target".

Input Format : An integer array representing the items. Another integer array representing the scores of those items by the user. And lastly, an int T denoting the desired target score. Output Format : All possible combinations of two elements from different lists so long they meet the condition of being added together to get exactly the same number as the target. Sample I/O : [[1],[2]], [[3]] Target Value=1 Expected Answer:[(1,1),(2,1)] Sample II/O : [[1,2,3],[4,5,6],[7,8,9]] Target Value=12 Expected Answer:([(1,4), (2,5)), (3,6), (7,8), (9,9)] Sample III/O : [[1,2,3,4],[5,6,7,8,9]] Target Value=11 Expected Answer:([(1,5), (2,6), (3,7), (4,8)])

### 177. LRU Cache

        `id` INTEGER PRIMARY KEY AUTOINCREMENT,
        `name` TEXT UNIQUE NOT NULL,
        `preferences` TEXT
      );"""
        
    print('Creating user table...')
    try:
        c.execute(sqlCreateTableIfNotExists)
    except sqllite.IntegrityError:
        pass
            
    # insert into table
    sqlInsertIntoTable = f'''INSERT INTO "user" ("id", "name", "preferences") VALUES ('{str(date.today().year)}','{input()}');'''.format(**locals())
    print(sqlInsertIntoTable)
    c.execute(sqlInsertIntoTable)
                  
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()

### Part II - ETL Processing  ###

Create an ETL process using HiveQL in order to load data from the IMDB database into your own MySQL instance running on Google Cloud Platform (GCP). Your GCP project ID will not change throughout all tasks of the assignment so you do not have to re-create the project every time. Note down your project ID somewhere safe as you will use it later.

The schema of the destination table should match closely with the source table but not exactly since we are adding extra fields here such as the user preference history field which does not exist in the source table. To achieve this, create two new files called `schema_movie_recommendation.sql` and `load_movies_from_imdb.sql`. Both these scripts should live inside `/hdfs/user/studentid/` directory where studentID is replaced by yours. For example if I was student number **8** then my hdfs path would look like this: ```/hdfs/user/8```

You must run both scripts before moving onto the next step otherwise there may be problems when trying to execute the second script. This is because the first script creates temporary tables while the second one tries to read them. If they don't exist yet then there won't be any data available to read. Run each file separately after updating the path variable at the top.

After creating the required schema, move over to `load_movies_from_imdb.sql` and write the actual code needed to populate the target table. This should consist mainly of the DML commands necessary to copy rows between different databases. There is also some additional logic required to handle null values coming back from the source database. In particular, there needs to be handling around how null values get passed through during joins. See below for more details about this topic.

#### Null Handling ####
In our case we are copying records across multiple databases. Because of this, it means that sometimes the value returned from the previous database might contain NULL values instead of the expected data type. Whenever a row gets copied over with a NULL value, what happens behind the scenes depends on whether the column has been declared as NOT NULL or NOTNULL in the CREATE TABLE statement.

### 7 - Batch Processing
Write an application which allows you to batch process files in your directory into a CSV file using a command line interface. Your program must support both single-file processing as well as multiple-files processing.

Command Line Interface:
```bash
Usage:
    $./batchProcessFiles <path> [-h|--help] [-s|--singleFile] [-m|--multipleFiles]
Options:
    --help     Show help message                                              []
                true
    --singleFile       Single File Processing Only                            []
                false
    --multipleFiles   Multiple Files Processing Only                          []
                false
Examples:
    # Processes a single file
    $./batchProcessFiles./example/input.txt

    # Processes multiple files
    $./batchProcessFiles./example/input.txt../example/output.csv
```
The application supports both single-file processing as well as multiple-files processing by default. To enable either of these features, use one of the flag options `-s` or `-m`. If no flags are passed then the default behaviour will be used.

Example Usage:
```bash
$./batchProcessFiles./example/input.txt -s
$./batchProcessFiles./example/input.txt -m
```

Write an application that recommends movies based on user ratings provided through the CLI. Your app should allow users to rate any number of films from 1 star upwards to 5 stars. Whenever they do so, the corresponding rating should be stored within the application along with other information about each film such as its genre(s). This data could come directly from IMDB if desired but feel free to create your own dataset instead! Once enough people have rated certain titles highly over time then those films become more likely candidates when searching through our library catalogue; thus making sure we always serve relevant content everytime someone visits us online :)

### Question #6 - Create an Object-Oriented Database Model in MySQL Workbench ##

Create an object-oriented database model using MySQL work bench. This model will allow you to store data about actors from different films. Your model must have the following classes and properties:
Class Actor
Property Name: Firstname Property Type: String
Property Name: Lastname Property Type: String
Property Name: Birthyear Property Type: Integer
Property Name: Death year Property type: Integer
Property Name: Film Roles Property Type: List of Strings
Class Movie
Property Title Property Type: string
Property Release Year Property Type: integer
Property Genre Property Type: list of strings
Class Role
Property Character played Property Type: string
Property Actress/Actor property Type: string
Property Scene count Property Type: integer
Property Credits property Type: boolean

You may create as many other classes as necessary but they are not required.

### Question #7 - Develop a PHP Script to Implement the Recommendation System ###

The next step after developing your database schema is to implement a script that takes user inputs and makes queries against the database table to return recommended titles given the input information provided by the user. For example, if I enter "action" into the input box then my script would make a query to get all rows where genre contains any row containing the word "Action". Then the script should take those returned values and order them by popularity first and then alphabetically.

MySQL: https://dev.mysql.com/doc/refman/8.0/en/select.html
PHP: http://php.net/manual/en/function.usort.php

### Question #8 - Construct a Data Dictionary for the Movie Recommender System ###

Once we have our database schema defined along with some logic implemented within our PHP script, we now need to construct what is called a “Data dictionary”. A data dictionary provides us with information such as field names, types, constraints etc., which allows us to define how data is stored within each column so that applications can read it properly when reading back out again later down stream during processing time frames once processed through various business rules before being sent off for further analysis via analytical tools.

In addition, there’s also another important piece here – metadata! Metadata tells developers things about certain pieces of code

package main
import "fmt"
func main() {
	// Get user preference history from the command line arguments.
    var history []string = make([]string, len(os.Args)) // Create an empty array of strings called `history` using the built-in function `make`. This will store all user's previous movies watched.
    
    if len(os.Args) > 1 && os.Args[1] == "-h" || os.Args[len(os.Args)-1] == "--help"{  
        fmt.Println("Usage:", os.Args[0], "[<user preference history>]" )                         // Print out help message when no other argument are passed into the program except -h flag.
            return;                      // Exit the application immediately upon detecting the usage information provided by the user.
        }else if len(os.Args) < 2{       // If there isn't any additional argument besides '-h' then print out some instructions about how we use our application.
                fmt.Print("\n")             // Newline character to separate each instruction/command properly
                fmt.Println(`
                          Usage:`, os.Args[0])              // User's preferred movie list must be specified as second parameter after `-h` flag was removed
                fmt.Println(``)               // End of the instruction section
                fmt.Print("\n\n")           // Newline character again since we have finished printing the first part of instructions.
                fmt.Println("Examples:\n")    // Start new paragraph before continuing with more explanation on what exactly does our tool do.
                fmt.Println("```")            // Line break so everything won't appear like one long sentence which makes things easier to read through later on!
                fmt.Println("$ ", os.Args[0], "\n")
                fmt.Println("$ ", os.Args[0], " --help \n")
                fmt.Println("$ ", os.Args[0], " 12 Angry Men (1957)\n")

# Movielens

## Description
The `movielens` package contains data from the MovieLens dataset which was created by collaborative filtering service Netflix Inc., in order to create user profiles using data mining algorithms. It consists of over two million ratings given by about half a million unique individuals who have rated between one thousand and fourteen thousands films during more than eight years since its creation.

This package provides an interface to access the data stored as SQLite databases through Python. These are: * `ml-1m`, containing the original rating matrix; * `ml-latest`, storing the latest version available at time of writing (*i.e.*, December 2018); * `ml-1m-genre`, containing only genre information; and * `ml-1m-user`.

"""

import sqlite3 as sqlc
conn = sqlc.connect('imdb.sqlite') #Open connection to.sql file
cur = conn.cursor()            #Create cursor object in order to execute queries
query = "SELECT * FROM title_basics WHERE tconst='science-fiction'"    #Select all titles from table 'title_basics', where column value of tconst equals'science-fiction'.
# Execute SELECT statement by calling method.execute().
results = cur.execute(query)                   #Return rows obtained after execution of select statement.
# Iterate over each row (i.e., each element in list).
for i in range(len(results)):                #Get values from current row returned by function.fetchall(), which returns a list containing values stored in corresponding fields.
     print("{}: {}".format(i+1, results[0][7]))

### Problem B - Movielens (Medium):

Create an ETL pipeline using Python for processing and analyzing data from Amazon’s MovieLens dataset. Your program will take as input the file “moviedata-omr.csv” located under the directory “data/ml-1M”. The first line of the file contains metadata about the dataset. Each row represents one user who rated different films during a particular time period. For each film rating, include the ID number of both the film and the user who gave the review; also include the date when the review was given.

In your ETL process, consider the following steps:
* Convert the ratings into binary values by assigning 1 if they are above 3 stars otherwise assign zero. This way we can calculate similarities among reviews and filter out spammy users.
* Calculate the similarity score of every pair of users, which can then be used to compute the similarity matrix.
* Filter out irrelevant rows such as those where either the user has no other reviewed movies apart from the ones already included in the dataset or the same movie is being recommended multiple times.
* Compute the average similarity of all pairs of users and store it in a new column called ‘similarity’.
* Create a new column named ‘totalSimilarity’ containing the sum of the scores calculated earlier.
* Find the top K most similar users (K = 20). Also find the corresponding top K most similar movies and display them along with their similarity score.

Note: Please ensure that you have read the instructions carefully before starting work on the problem since there might not always be enough time left over at the end for clarifications after the submission deadline passes. If needed please ask questions early so that everyone gets ample opportunity to answer any queries prior to commencing work! Thank you :)


### Problem C - Movie Reviews(Hard):

You were asked to implement a recommender algorithm that uses collaborative filtering technique. Given some ratings provided by people, the goal is to predict how much another person would like a specific item. In order to do this, you will build up a model that takes previous items someone liked together with his/her current interest and computes the likelihood of him/her liking yet another unseen item.

### Part C - Data Modeling - 90/86 points

You have been hired as an intern by Netflix in order to build out the backend data modeling component of its new movie recommendation engine. This project will consist of three parts:

This part requires the implementation of the relational design using MySQL Workbench. To complete this assignment successfully, please read all instructions carefully before beginning work.

#### Instructions

The first step toward building any successful product is understanding how customers use it. In order to understand customer usage patterns, Netflix needs to collect information from them about what they are watching now and what they want to watch next. This information comes primarily through two sources:

1. Customer’s view history: What titles did the user previously select? When was each selection made? How long were these selections viewed? Were there other factors involved such as when was each item selected, where did the user search for it, etc.?
2. User profile: Age, gender, interests, location, relationship status, occupation, income level, education level, home ownership, marital status, religion, ethnicity, race, sexual orientation, political affiliation, height, weight, body type, hair color, eye color, skin tone, piercings & tattoos, musical taste, food preference, TV shows watched, books read, sports teams followed… basically everything else!

Netflix wants to store both pieces of information together so that it knows not just which movies people liked but also why those choices might make sense given who they are as individuals—and vice versa. Therefore we'll create two separate tables called “viewHistory” and “userProfile”. Each table contains four fields: id (primary key), timestamp (date time stamp), titleID (foreign key referencing another table), and value(text). Note: If possible try avoiding foreign keys because they tend slow down queries significantly due too much overhead being spent determining whether something belongs somewhere else instead focusing solely on retrieving actual content itself; however sometimes necessary depending upon circumstances surrounding particular situation at hand during development process. ### Questions ###

#### What are the steps you took when writing your code? ####
I started by creating a schema which included all the table names as well as a list of column names within each one. Then i created an empty array called "movies" where i would store my recommended films from imdb's data set. After that, i iterated over every row inside the rating table and used its values to populate the "movies" array. Lastly i looped through these arrays again using the user preference history as criteria so they could compare similarities between them before returning true/false if there was enough similarity found between both sets.

#### Did anything about the assignment surprise you? If yes, what surprised you most about the assignment? ####
Yes! It did actually because after running my script i noticed how fast everything ran compared to other languages such as python etc... This made me realize just how powerful java really is when working with large datasets like those provided here today :)

---
### HW-06 - SQL Injection Attack
In your own words describe how an attacker could use SQL injection in order to extract sensitive data from the database of a banking application. Provide examples if possible. Explain what measures are needed to prevent such attacks?

To execute any command against a SQL server we must first create a valid username/password combination then inject our commands into the user supplied parameter value. An example would be like the one below:
```sql
--Create User
CREATE USER 'John' IDENTIFIED BY '<your password here>'
GO
```
Now when John executes his queries he will have access to everything in the database including all passwords.
As far as prevention goes there are many ways but the most basic method is to always check every incoming request and sanitize them before sending them off to the database. This means no special character filters which is a huge security risk because some special characters may not seem dangerous at face value yet they actually do something behind the scenes.

---

"""

# Import libraries
import sys
sys.path.append("../../../")
from collections import Counter # Used for counting unique values from lists/arrays of strings
from itertools import groupby   # Used for grouping elements by common properties
from operator import itemgetter    # Used as an iterator function which allows us to access individual items within a list

# --------------------------------------------------------------
# Function definitions
def main():
	# Get user input
	userInput = str(input('Enter your favorite movies separated by commas:\n'))
	userPreferenceHistory = []                            # Create empty array used for storing history information
	for word in userInput.split(','):
		if len(word)>=6:     # If user input contains more than six letters then add them into preference history
			userPreferenceHistory += ["".join([char if char.isalpha() else '_' for char in word])]+"\n"]
	else:               # Otherwise just append the string directly onto the preference history
		userPreferenceHistory+=["".join([char if char.isalpha() else '_' for char in word])+ "\n"]

	# Sort and remove duplicates
	userPrefHistorySortedDuplicates = sorted(Counter(list(set(itemgetter(*userPreferenceHistory)))))[::-1].values().pop(-1).strip("\n").replace('\r','')         # Returning the last element in the dictionary after removing all duplicate values
	print(userPrefHistorySortedDuplicates)       # Print out the preferred titles

main()

### Part B - Movie Recommendation System (5 Marks)
You will have access to the MySQL database created in part A of your assignment as well as some additional information about each film from the IMDB website. Your task is to use these two sources of data to implement an algorithm/model which generates recommended movies to show to new customers who walk into a cinema.
In order to do so you must first define the variables required by your model such as user preference history (array), number of customer requests per day etc.. Once defined you are free to write any code necessary but here’s where things get tricky…you cannot make any assumptions about how many people request what films! This means that every time someone walks through your door there could potentially be another person asking for something different – so even though one might assume they know exactly what kinda stuff other folks like seeing at nighttime hours after work – we don't actually know until later down line when those numbers come out via statistics & surveys done afterwards."

**Hint #1:** There may not always be enough room available inside our building because sometimes there isn't enough space left over after all seats were filled up during peak times earlier today; however if anyone wants extra tickets then please let me know immediately!" **Hint #2:** If no one shows up tonight than I guess everyone went home early instead...or maybe just got tired before dinner ended? Either way sounds pretty boring doesn't matter either way since neither option would allow us much choice anyway unless somebody else had already bought them off course then again nowadays everything seems possible thanks largely due mostly likely because nobody knows anything anymore ;)

### Part C - Predictive Modelling (7 marks)
The final step involves predicting future events using machine learning algorithms trained upon past data sets provided by third parties e g Twitter Facebook YouTube Google+ etceteras. These predictions include things such as whether someone will click ads, buy products online watch videos listen podcasts read articles share posts comment tweet ++++++etc....

select t.* from title_basics as t join title_rating r on t.titleId = r.titleId where avg(r.averageRating)>=7;
```

The above code returns all titles in which the average rating of each title is greater than 7.

# 79. Movie Ratings Prediction Using Naive Bayes Classifier
Write an SQL query to retrieve all movies from the IMDB database where the rating is less than 6 out of 10 stars.

The data set contains two tables: ratings and titles. Table "titles" has fields such as id, year, title, etc., while table "ratings" consists of fields like id, vote_count, rating, tname, which stands for the corresponding title's ID.

**Constraints**  
Use SQL syntax correctly in your queries.

# 80. Movie Reviews Data Analysis using R
Write a Python program to analyze the sentimental analysis of reviews related to the movie “Avengers Endgame”. Use the data provided below as training dataset.

Movie Name | Review Sentiment | Total Number Of Reviews
-----------|--------------------|-------------
Avenger’s End Game | Positive | 8936
Captain Marvel | Negative | 1209
Jumanji | Neutral | 1041
Spider Man Far From Home | Positive | 1451
Toy Story 4 | Positive | 1782

This is how we will evaluate our model performance:

Sentiment Score = TP / (TP+FP + FN). We will get the number of positive reviews and negative review by applying tfidf vectorization method over the textual data. Then we calculate the ratio between them. This gives us the final score for sentiment classification.

**Constraints**

# 17. Task 10 - SQL Developers
Implement a simple application that will allow students to enroll into classes using a web form.  Create a table called class with fields courseID, courseNumber, creditHours, semester, yearOffered; create another table called section with fields id, courseSection, instructor, capacity, availableSeats; finally create one more table called registration with fields studentID, term, sectionID, status. Each row in each table represents a unique record. For example if we assume there are three sections in a particular class offered during Spring Semester then there would be three rows representing these sections under the section table. Now when a user submits a request through a Web Form, your program needs to check whether all seats are filled up or not by retrieving data from the section table. If all seats are already full then the submission fails otherwise the user gets successfully registered. In order to store submitted information use the above mentioned tables and insert new records accordingly. Your program must also display the number of registrants per class.

### Part B - 

Now you will add additional features by adding an extra column in your table called `rating`. This rating could either be `true` if they have seen the film before or false otherwise. Also, instead of using the `startyear`, `endyear`, etc., we would rather use the year that the user has specified as their preferred time period (`timePeriod`). Finally, we want to include a new feature whereby the user can specify more than one genre so we introduce another column named `genreLists` which stores all the possible combinations between `titleGenreId` and `userPreferenceGenreIds`.
The final schema should look something like this:
```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS movies(
	movieID INT PRIMARY KEY AUTO_INCREMENT,
    title_id VARCHAR(8),
    tconst VARCHAR(8),
    titleType VARCHAR(8),
    primaryTitle VARCHAR(8),
    originalTitle VARCHAR(8),
    isAdult BOOL DEFAULT FALSE,
    startYEAR INTEGER UNSIGNED,
    endYEAR INTEGER UNSIGNED,
    runtimeMINUTES FLOAT UNSIGNED,
    genres TEXT[],
    avgRatings NUMERIC(7, 2),
    numVOTE NUMBER(10) UNSIGNED,
    director VARCHAR(8)[],
    writer VARCHAR(8)[],
    principal CHARACTERS[]);
ALTER TABLE movies ADD COLUMN rating BOOLEAN;
ALTER TABLE movies ADD COLUMN timePeriod DATE;
ALTER TABLE movies ADD COLUMN genreLists TEXT[];

query: I was thinking of a nice, animal movie.
output:
'''
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS userInput;
INSERT INTO userInput VALUES ('I want to watch an animal movie');

SELECT tb.* FROM
( SELECT DISTINCT tc.titleId AS tId, CONCAT('movies.', tc.titleId,'/') AS tURL
FROM movies
JOIN titles ON movies.movieId = titles.id
WHERE CONTAINS((titles.titleBasics),'animal')) AS tb INNER JOIN
userInput USING (tb.tUrl);

UNION ALL

SELECT tb.* FROM
( SELECT DISTINCT tc.titleId AS tId, CONCAT('movies.', tc.titleId,'/') AS tURL
FROM movies
JOIN titles ON movies.movieId = titles.id
WHERE CONTAINS((titles.titleBasics),'animal'));
-- Union all will join two queries together into one table called tb where each row in the first query gets matched by rows from second query.
'''

Hint: you may use the following table schema in your queries: https://www.imdb.com/interfaces/?rs=api&pa=title-rating.json

'''
import pandas as pd
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
from sqlalchemy.orm import sessionmaker
from pprint import pformat
from sqlalchemy import func
# Importing Dataset
dataset = pd.read_csv("data.csv")
# Creating engine instance
engine = create_engine('sqlite:///:memory:') # SQLite memory backend
SessionLocal = sessionmaker(bind=engine)
session = SessionLocal() # Create new local session
# Making Dataframe into a dict of dictionaries
dfdict = {i[0]: i[1:] for i in dataset}
# Convert Dicts into Lists
dlist = list(map(lambda x :x[0], dfdict))
rlist = list(map(lambda x :x[1:-1], dfdict))
# Generating Unique Values from Dictionaries using set function
unique_values = set([x for y in rlist for x in y])
# Combining unique values & dictionary lists
combined_vals = dlist + unique_values
# Converting combined vals back to dataframe
newdf = pd.DataFrame(combined_vals).transpose().reset_index(drop=True)
# Selecting desired fields from data frame
result = newdf[(newdf["title"] == "Moana")]
# Saving the final df locally
finalDF = result.to_dict()
# Displaying Results
pprint(finalDF)

You have successfully generated your first SQL query but we want to see how much more creative you can be! In addition to providing us just one SQL query like before, now let's add an extra layer of complexity by adding another table called "user_preferences" into our schema along with two additional columns called "user_id" and "movie_rating". output:
The table title_ratings has two columns - rating and votes.
We will use the average of all ratings as our rating score. So if we have N movies rated by M people then the average rating would be : [(sum(rating)/M)]/N

The table title_reviews has four columns - avg_rating,num_voters,title_id,user_name. We want the highest rated movies so we filter out everything else using the above criteria.

The table titles_casting contains five fields- job, character, category, orderinig, nconst. Since there are multiple actors who played different roles in each film we sort them according to their ordering field. Now we calculate how many times an actor appeared in which type of role e.g. lead, supporting etc.. To do this we create another table called casting_types containing three fields- nconst, categories,jobs where jobs contain values like lead,supporting,etc...Now we select from both these tables and count the number of appearances of each actor under every category. Finally we take the top ten most frequent appearing actors and add up their total appearances into one column. This way we get the most frequently acting actors.

The last step is to find those films whose main stars also had other starring roles. For example if Leonardo Dicaprio was playing the leading role but he also acted as a supporting role we consider him as having more than one role in that particular film. We just need to sum up the numbers given in the previous steps.

Output:
[{'actor': 'Leonardo DiCaprio', 'appearances': 9}, {'actor': 'Jason Bateman', 'appearances': 8}]

### 7-E. Movie Recommendation System - Part II

This challenge requires you to implement the functionality of a movie recommendation system as described below. For simplicity sake we will use the same data set provided above but there are two key differences between these challenges:

* **Input** - In Challenge #6 your user input was hard coded into the SQL statement which resulted in poor performance when running against large datasets. This time around you must accept an input parameter passed through GET request so that each unique value has its own separate SQL statement generated.
* **Output** - Instead of returning a simple list of movies like before now you must return a JSON object containing additional information about the movie including a brief synopsis of what it’s all about!

In addition to generating the SQL statements we also want some help understanding how many queries were run during execution since multiple different combinations could potentially exist depending upon user preference history size etc.. We ask that if possible please include both number queries ran along side any other relevant metrics such as total cost spent doing work etc…

Movie Recommendation System
=========================
------------------------------

# Movie Recommender
## Table Designs
* Title Basics - titleID(pk), ttype(int), primtitle(varchar(64)), origtitle(varchar(64)), adult(boolean), yearstart(int), yearyear(int), runmin(float), genreid(int)
* Title Ratings - avgrating(float), votecnt(integer)
* Name Basics - nname(pk), const(string), ybirth(date), ddeath(date), pprof(string), kftitle(string[])
* Title Crew - dir(string[]), wrtr(string[]), cast(string[])
* Title Principal Cast - ord(integer), cnt(integer), cat(string), jjob(string), charexists(bool)

## Data Models & Relational Diagrams
![Data Model](https://github.com/christopherlangevin/movieRecommender/blob/master/dataModel.png "Data Model")

### Primary Keys
The primary key of each table in my database is as follows:
```sql
titleID int PRIMARY KEY AUTO INCREMENT;
nname varchar(64);
ord integer NOT NULL DEFAULT 0;
cname varchar(64);
job varchar(8);
year float;
genreId int;
avg rating float;
votecnt int;
```

### Foreign Key Constraints
There are no foreign keys used within any of these models. I have not included them because there were none necessary in my data model.

#### Tables
|Table | Columns | Description |
|---|---|---|
|titleBasics | titleID | title type |
|titleBasics | primTitle | Original Title |
|titleBasics | originTitle | Alternative Titile |
|titleBasics | Adult | Is Rated Mature? |
|titleBasics | YearStart | Start Date |
|titleBasics | Yearyear | Ending date |
|titleBasics | RunTime | Duration |
|titleBasics | GenreId | Category ID |
|titleRatings | AverageRating | Average Overall

All these tables together form an RDBMS which stands for Relational Database Management System. We call them relations because they relate information from multiple sources into one centralized location where anyone can access those data through queries written by programmers who know how to work with databases like MySQL among others. A relational database management system stores related information about entities within its own schema structure called tables. In addition, each entity may belong to zero or many attributes depending upon what kind of object model was used during design phase when creating new tables inside our application framework project file (.php extension).

query: Hello, I am looking for something like the A Game of Thrones
output:
```sql
select * from 
(select tb.*,tr.*,tb.* as rated, nb.*,tc.*,np.*,tb.* as actor, tc.* as writer
from imdb.title_basics tb
inner join imdb.name_basic np using(primaryName),
imdb.rating_basis tr inner join imdb.title_ratings tc where rating>=6/10 and rating<=8/10
inner join imdb.title_crew tc using(director),
imdb.title_principals tp using(character)
where tb.titleType='movie'
and np.deathYear=null
and tp.category>='actor') r;
order by rated desc limit 10;```

### 16 - Movie Recommendation System II

In your last assignment you were able to create a simple movie recommendation engine by using a relational model. Now we want to improve upon that design by adding additional features such as filtering of movies according to user preference history, additionally recommending other actors who have starred in similar movies etc.. This will require us to use an object orientated approach instead of simply storing all data in one table.

This time around we are going to use a MySQL database with four different tables which represent our objects. Each table has its own unique identifier column so there won't any issues when joining them together later during processing phase where we extract relevant information from each row before returning back some meaningful values through SELECT queries.

## Part II - Execution of SQL Queries in Python

Write an implementation of your SQL queries in python using the pyodbc module. This will allow you to execute SQL statements against the provided data from part I.
You may use any of these modules if they are available locally to you;
- MySQLdb
- psycopg2
- pymssql
- mysql.connector

The code must include the following items;
* Create a connection string object to connect to the DBMS specified above
* A function called "recommendMovies" which takes user input as arguments and returns a list of recommended titles.
    * The function should first validate whether there are enough entries in the preference history table for the given user. If not, then no recommendations would be returned by the function. Otherwise, a set of recommendations shall be retrieved from the database by executing the SQL query generated during phase one.
        * The returned values could either be the actual title names, or the IDs of those records so long as the user has access rights over them. In other words, we don't want to return private information such as phone numbers etc., just because the user happens to have seen something before! So please make sure you handle privacy correctly here too :)

```sql
select * from (
    select tc.*, nr.*, count(*) as voteCount
        from title_rating tr inner join rating r
            on tr.titleID = r.movieID
                AND r.userID=?
                   group by r.movieID,r.userID;
     union all
         SELECT tc.*, nr.* FROM title_casting tc INNER JOIN title_principal np ON tc.titleId = np.titleid WHERE np.job IN ('actor','director') GROUP BY np.titleid HAVING COUNT(np.nameID)>1 ORDER BY COUNT(np.nameID);
    ) nr where userID=? order by nr.voteCount desc limit? offset?
```

### Part B - ETL process ###
In part A you have created an SQL query that returns all of the recommended movies given your user input parameters. Now we want to create a new table in our data warehouse containing all of these movies so they are available for further analysis using tools such as Tableau. To do this, we will use SSIS which allows us to extract information from one source and load into another destination where it can then be analyzed by other business intelligence systems like PowerBI etc.. This section describes how to write SSIS packages to perform both tasks; extracting data from IMDB's Movie Recommendation Database into Azure Data Lake Gen2 storage account & loading them back up again after processing within Power Bi Desktop application running locally!
