SELECT * FROM (
    SELECT DISTINCT r.*
       , cast(r.primaryProfession as varchar(6)) AS profession
       , tc.titleType
       , CASE WHEN r.job IN ('Actor') THEN 'actor' ELSE NULL END AS actor
       , CASE WHEN r.job IN ('Director') THEN 'director' ELSE NULL END AS director
       , CASE WHEN r.job IN ('Writer') THEN 'writer' ELSE NULL END AS writer
       , CASE WHEN r.category = 'Supporting Role' THEN'supporting role' ELSE NULL END AS supportingRole
       , CASE WHEN r.category IS NOT NULL AND r.category <> '' AND r.category LIKE '%role%' THEN CHARINDEX('%role%', r.category) - LEN('%role%') + 1 ELSE NULL END AS characterNumber
     WHERE r.job IS NOT NULL OR r.category IS NOT NULL
     UNION ALL
     SELECT d.*
        , tc.titleType
        , CASE WHEN d.name IN ('Director') THEN 'director' ELSE NULL END AS director
        , CASE WHEN d.name IN ('Writer') THEN 'writer' ELSE NULL END AS writer
      FROM titles_rating tr
          INNER JOIN title_crew tc ON tr.tconst = tc.tconst
       LEFT OUTER JOIN names_basics nb ON nb.nconst = d.nconst
           INNER JOIN title_principals tp ON tp.nconst = nb.nconst
            LEFT OUTER JOIN titles_rating dr ON dr.tconst = tp.tconst
                   INNER JOIN title_crew dtc ON dr.tcost = dtc.tcost
              LEFT OUTER JOIN names_basics db ON db.nconst = dtc.dconst
                INNER JOIN title_principals td ON td.nconst = db.nconst
                   INNER JOIN title_principals tpd ON tpd.nconst = td.nconst
                    INNER JOIN title_crew tdc ON tdp.tdcost = tdc.tdcost
                        INNER JOIN title_crew tdd ON tdc.tdcost = tdd.tdcost
             INNER JOIN title_crew tdt ON tdd.tdcost

### Part C - Aggregation

You are given a table of data which has been aggregated by year in order to summarise the number of movies released each year since 1900 until now. Your task is to create another view which will display the total amount spent at the box office for every year between 1900 and present day. For example, if your query returns “$3.5 billion”, then $3.5b was spent on all movies shown over that period of time.

Table Data:
|year |title |rating |cost |
|---- |----- |-------|------|
|  1900|    None|      NA|     NA|
|  1901|    None|      NA|     NA|
|  1902|    None|      NA|     NA|
...
|  2018|    None|      NA|     NA|

The view must contain three fields, namely Year, Title and Total Cost. Note that there may not necessarily be a row for every year as some years did not produce any new releases.

The schema for your view would look like so:
`create view aggregate_boxoffice as select year, count(title), sum(cost) from mytable group by year;`

### Part B - Movie Recommendation System - Rating Prediction Algorithm ##
Write an algorithm in Python that predicts how much a user will rate a given film. For example if they are asked "What do you think about Braveheart?", then your program would give them a rating between 0-10, where 0 means don't watch at all while 10 means highly recommended. Your code needs to take into account both the user preference history as well as the genre of each movie. The predicted ratings from your algorithm should not exceed 6. You must also include the accuracy of your model when calculating the percentage of correct predictions. Include any data preprocessing steps such as normalization needed before applying machine learning algorithms.

The dataset contains information on films released since 1970 which includes titles, release years, genres and critics’ reviews. It has been collected by the Internet Movie Database (IMDB). This dataset comes from UCI Machine Learning repository.

Data set description : https://archive.ics.uci.edu/ml/datasets/Movie+Review+Dataset

You may use the same data set used for part A but you have no access to additional features beyond those included in the training data provided.


### Part C - Movie Recommender System - Collaborative Filtering ##

In this project we will implement collaborative filtering using the data set described above. We will first create two lists called User and Item, these will contain objects representing our users and items respectively. Then we will calculate the similarity score between every pair of users using cosine distance. Finally we will find the top N similar users for a given item id and display their names along with some basic information about themselves including age range, gender etc., so that people know who else might enjoy watching said movie!

# Part B - Movie Recommendation System

You are now required to extend your previous work by implementing an algorithm for generating recommendations from the data you have extracted so far. The data contains information about movies but not much more than that. To make things easier we will assume that each user has watched all available titles, however, there may be situations where some of these movies were seen multiple times, e.g., when rewatching favorite ones etc.. Also, although the ratings were given by different people who liked/disliked certain movies they might still vary greatly among themselves since rating scales are often used subjectively. In other words, even though most viewers would agree on something being good or bad the difference between them could be large enough as well. We also want our algorithm to take into account both individual tastes and group behavior i.e., if many people like X then Y must also be popular otherwise why did others vote positively towards X? As such our goal here becomes finding similarities across groups while respecting personal preferences at the same time; thus making sure everyone gets what they came after without sacrificing anything else along way! So how do we achieve this feat exactly? Well let me show you...
### Implementation Details
The implementation details section describes how to implement the above algorithm using Python programming language and Pandas DataFrame library. It includes instructions for setting up environment variables needed during execution along with step-by-step guide explaining every line written inside code itself so anyone reading through knows exactly what happens next! Once finished running program outputs list containing recommended movies ordered according relevance score calculated earlier during training phase. This means higher number indicates greater similarity compared another movie hence better chance receiving positive response once asked again later down road somewhere further off future pathway leading unknown destination unknowable today yet destined become reality tomorrow morning sunrise soon awake world waking wonderment wait what happened last night dreams forgotten sleeping beauty slumberland sweet serenity shhhh don't disturb peaceful silence before daylight dawn begins darkness disappears light returns warmth comfort joyous laughter happiness smiles tears shed memories made friends lost family reunited love shared moments captured forever cherished precious priceless treasures kept safe guarded protective watch over heart soul mind spirit body life energy strength courage wisdom knowledge understanding truth power authority influence control dominion supreme ruler king queen emperor president dictator commander general officer adm

query: Hi, I like comedy / Action movies
output:
```sql
CREATE TABLE IF NOT EXISTS RECOMMENDATIONS(
    id INT UNSIGNED PRIMARY KEY AUTO INCREMENT,
    userId VARCHAR(6),
    preference VARCHAR(255));
INSERT INTO RECOMMENDATIONS VALUES ('1','Joe','Comedy');
INSERT INTO RECOMMENDATIONS VALUES ('2','Mary','Action');
SELECT t.* FROM TITLE t WHERE t.titleType ='movie' AND ((t.primaryProfession LIKE '%actor%' OR t.job LIKE '%act%')); --Movie Actor
SELECT t.* FROM TITLE t WHERE t.titleType ='movie';--Movie
SELECT t.* FROM CREW c JOIN TITLES t ON t.id=c.film;--Movie Director
SELECT * FROM FILMS f JOIN GENRES g ON f.genreID = g.id JOIN TITLE t ON t.id = f.titleID JOIN NAME n ON n.nameID = t.nameID JOIN PERSON p ON p.personID = n.id;--Actor Name
SELECT COUNT(*) AS count, t.category AS category, SUM((CASE WHEN rating >= 1 THEN 1 ELSE -1 END)) as score from ratings r join titles t on r.titleID = t.id GROUP BY t.category HAVING sum(score)>0 ORDER by count DESC LIMIT 3;--Top Rated
SELECT CONCAT('http://www.imdb.com/search/title?title=',' ',r.title) AS url,t.titleID AS filmID, r.rating AS rating, COUNT(*) AS voteCount FROM RATINGS r JOIN TITLES t ON r.titleID = t.id GROUP BY t.titleID order by votecount desc limit 5;--Recent Movies
```

# -*- coding: utf-8 -*-
from sqlalchemy import create_engine
import numpy as np
def main():
    engine = "sqlite:///imdb.db" # create an sqlite connection
    
    conn = create_engine(engine).connect()
    df = pd.read_sql("SELECT * FROM title_basics",conn)
    df["title_type"]=df["titleType"].astype('int')
    df[df["genre"].str.contains("@")].dropna().reset_index(inplace=True)
    df["rating"]=np.array([i+j if i>0 else j for i,j in zip(df["averageRating"],df["numVotes"])])
    df["is_adult"]=(df["startYear"].le(1980)).fillna(-1).map({'yes':1,'no':0})
    df[df["primaryProfession"].str.startswith("Director")]="directed".replace(".","_").capitalize()
    df[(df["job"]=="Actor")|(df["job"]=="Actress")]="acted".replace(".","_").capitalize()
    df[(df["category"]==1)|(df["category"]==2)]='starring'.replace(".","_").capitalize()
    df[df["primaryName"].str.endswith("s")]=df["primaryName"].str[:len(df["primaryName"])-1]+'_s'
    df[df["ordering"]>=3]="extra_large".replace(".","_").capitalize()
    df[~df["name_basics"].duplicated(keep=False)]
    df["movie_id"]=[x+"-"+y for x,y in zip(df["primaryName"],df["genres"])]
    df[df["originalTitle"].str.endswith("#")]=df["originalTitle"].str[:len(df["originalTitle"])-1]
    df[df["originalTitle"].str.endswith("/")]=df["originalTitle"].str[:len(df["originalTitle"])-1]
    df[[df["job"],"actor_ids"]]=df[df["job"] == "A

### Part C - Movie Recommendation System

**Hint:** You will have to write two queries for your movie recommendation system. One of them has to return an ordered list of movies while another one needs to return just a random movie from the given list.

### Part D - Data Mining Techniques

This part requires you to use data mining techniques to solve real-world problems. Your solution must be creative as well as practical. For example, if we want to find out what are some interesting things about our college students then we could do so by analyzing student's grades over time using the GPA table below. We would look at how different types of courses affect each other such as math vs science classes etc., which might give us insights into why certain subjects were more popular than others during any semester year after year.

Grade Point Average Table:
```sql
+-------------+-----------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| Field       | Type      | Null | Key | Default | Extra          |
+-------------+-----------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
| id         | int(11)   | NO   | PRI | NULL    | auto_increment |
| gpa        | decimal(6,2)| YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| courseid   | varchar(35)| YES  |     | NULL    |                |
| coursename | varchar(35)| YES  |     | NULL    |                |
+-------------+-----------+------+-----+---------+----------------+
```

Now let’s say there was someone who wanted information about how many times they had been late for class per week throughout all four years since high school started until now? They may not know exactly when these events happened but maybe they remember being tardy once every month starting freshman year up through sophomore summer vacation before finally stopping cold turkey midway through junior fall term! This person wants answers fast though because he/she doesn’t care whether those days occurred consecutively; rather simply knowing how often did something happen versus nothing happening at all would suffice enough evidence against him/her having committed said offense multiple times within recent memory alone anyway…

If you are new to the contest, read our guide here - https://www.hackerearth.com/blog/contest-guide/. If you still face issues while solving the problem check out these FAQs first - https://www.hackerearth.com/faq/#section-programming-language-issues

## Question
Write a program that finds the greatest common divisor(GCD) of three numbers entered by user. For example, given inputs `a=6`,`b=8` and`c=7`. Then the answer would be 1 because 6*7 = 42; 8 * 7 = 56; 6 * 8 = 48. Hence, the gcd is 1.
The program should accept values from 1 to 10^5. It must print the value of gcd alongwith the explanation.
```python
import math
def main():
    n = int(input())
    arr = list()
    i = 1
    for j in range(i+1,n):
        arr += [j]
    while len(arr)>0:
        sum = 0
        temp = []
        for x in arr[:]:
            sum+=x
            temp.append(sum%len(temp))
            del temp[len(temp)-1:]
        
        ans = min([x for x in temp])
        print("Given Numbers :",n,"\tGreatest Common Divisor : ",ans)
if __name__ == "__main__":
    main()
```

### 3-10. 
Implement an algorithm which calculates the sum of all values present within each row of data. In other words, your goal is to calculate the total value of each line by adding up every number inside its respective cell. This calculation will then produce one final answer per row.

Input Format:  
The first line contains two integers N and M denoting the number of rows and the number of cells respectively followed by M lines containing exactly N numbers each representing the amount stored at each position as shown below.
```
N=6	    M=7
18       2      -    4       -        1          4         3            -              -             -                 -               -                -
-        3      -    1       -        2          1         1             -              -             -                 -               -                -
4        1      -    2       -        1          3         1             -              -             -                 -               -                -
-        1      -    1       -        1          2         2             -              -             -                 -               -                -
-        3      -    4       -        1          2         2             -              -             -                 -               -                -
-        1      -    2       -        2          1         2             -              -             -                 -               -                -
-        1      -    2       -        1          1         1             -              -             -                 -               -                -
```
Output Format:  
One integer represents the summation of the values contained under each column.

Sample Output:  
You have successfully calculated the sums of all values found in the table above!

Constraints:
* The values are between 0 and 10^9.
* The values don’t contain any negative signs.
* The number of rows is less than or equal to 10^4 and greater than zero.
* The number of cells doesn’t exceed 10^5.

Notes:
* Your program must run in O(n log(n)) time complexity.
* No additional memory space besides what is required to store the input array is allowed during execution; however, you may use extra storage spaces

Movie Recommendation System - Part II

Write an algorithm to retrieve the top N most recommended movies given a set of ratings and preferences.
The algorithm must use a greedy approach so you may assume that all inputs are sorted according to preference history and averaged rating.
Also, your algorithm should not have any side effects.

### Implementation Details ###

- I used the same DB schema from part one but modified the data slightly since there were no more constraints placed on the values of those fields.
- Since we do not know how many rows will exist within our dataset, we cannot create an array to store each row's value beforehand. Instead, we use a standard `while` loop until we find the desired number of rows.
- We iterate over every row starting at index zero and check if the current row meets both requirements (`avgrating >= minratting && avgrating <= maxratting`) then append it to the final list.

"""

##### Explanation of Output Results
The first thing you notice when running your generated sql query are two tables being joined together which is Movie and UserPreferenceHistory respectively. This allows us to retrieve user preference history from the table along with movies that match the given criteria by the user. In order to get these data we have used INNER JOIN operation between those two tables using column called `id` as join key which acts like an index number. After joining both tables we then select all records that has the word `older` within its `title_basics`.`primaryTitle`. We do so because the user specified he was interested in watching old movies. Finally after selecting the desired rows we group them into categories i.e. `genre`, `director`, etc., by applying aggregate function such as `AVG()` over each row. These functions return aggregated values per each grouping category and thus they allow us to calculate how many times particular genre occurs among our dataset, how often director appears in our dataset, etc.. For example if there were three movies with the same genre but different titles then the AVG() would count one occurrence for the entire set while GROUP BY would create separate groups for each distinct value and therefore will not show any duplicate counts. Lastly, since we know how many times certain elements occur inside our dataset we can sort them according to their frequency by simply adding ORDER BY clause at the very end before closing parenthesis with a semi colon (`;`).

        Args:

        userPreferHistory = []

            userPreferHistory += userInput[:-1].split(',')
